Award.AwardTitle: The Advanced Technology Environment and Energy Center: A Resource Center

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Advanced Technology Environmental Education Center (ATEEC) was established in 1994 as an NSF ATE Center of Excellence whose mission is to advance environmental technology education through curricula development, professional development, and program improvement in the nation's community colleges and secondary schools. This current project provides a comprehensive, market-driven Resource Center to promote professional development, teaching, training, and support to environmental and sustainable energy educational programs at the secondary and postsecondary levels. The Center has recently been renamed Advanced Technology Environment and Energy Center. The three major goals of this project are to expand ATEEC dissemination and availability of exemplary educational materials, curricula, and pedagogical practices in the areas of environmental and sustainable energy technology; to expand the web-based, digital electronic Environmental Resources Library (eERL) to include sustainable energy technology and expand the user base; and to provide professional development opportunities in the area of environmental and energy technology to high school and community college teachers. ATEEC works with business and industry, educators and government agencies to disseminate exemplary educational materials, curricula and resources in the areas of environmental and energy technology to high school and community college educators and students as well as technicians across the country. This project utilizes the national and regional Partnership for Environmental Technology Education networks, mailings, newsletters (print and electronic), the web-based eERL library, print information, exhibits, regional and national presentations, CD-ROMs, the ATEEC website, and journal articles to disseminate project activities, products, and environmental and energy technology education information.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Advanced Technology Environmental and Energy Center (ATEEC), an NSF ATE Center of Excellence, was established in 1994 with a mission to advance environmental technology education through curriculum development, professional development and program improvement in community colleges and secondary schools. In 2003, ATEEC became an ATE Resource Center and in 2007, ATEEC was additionally tasked
with expanding its expertise to build up sustainable energy technology
resources to meet the needs of students, educators, and industry to supply the sustainable energy field with trained technicians. ATEEC is operated through Eastern Iowa Community Colleges (EICC) and partners with the National Partnership for Environmental Technology Education (PETE) and the University of Northern Iowa (UNI).

ATEEC continues to evolve in order to better meet the changing needs of educators, students, technicians, and related NSF ATE projects to prepare environmental and energy technicians for current and future jobs. In August 2011, ATEEC opened new facilities which house ATEEC offices; the Interactive Learning Lab; classrooms and labs for credit and non-credit training programs; Environmental Health and Safety offices; and a Local Leaders exhibit showcasing local technology innovations to grow the entrepreneurial culture in environmental and energy fields. The new facility has allowed ATEEC to enhance the environmental and energy knowledge of educators, students, technicians, employers, and the public. This past year alone, the Interactive Learning Lab has been visited by over 4,500 people (mostly students). While at the lab, visitors can interact with diagnostic systems for solar panels and wind turbines which provide real-time energy production data, watch educational careers videos demonstrating various sustainable energy jobs and required skill sets for the jobs, and participate
in a variety of hands-on STEM activities.

ATEEC also expanded international activities. The partnership with Dalum College of Agriculture and the EUC-Syd Technical College in Denmark was enhanced through an NSF supplemental grant that allowed community college faculty and students from across the country to participate in a four-week institute in Denmark to study agriculture-based renewable energy technology in Europe. Information gained through international activities is incorporated into ATEEC activities, environment and energy curricula and the Resource Center website.

ATEEC’s activities are built on the specific needs of the nation’s environmental and energy education programs by facilitating occupational analysis workshops and forums across the country to ensure the input of business and industry. In 2009 and 2010, ATEEC facilitated NSF-funded Regional Energy Conversation forums to obtain a snapshot of existing and emerging energy jobs and to determine which jobs are currently needed and will soon be needed in different regions of the country in the area of energy. Information gathered from these forums was verified and validated at the National Energy Technician Education Summit held in December, 2010 in Washington, DC. Results can be found in ATEEC’s Preparing Energy Technicians for the 21st Century Workforce report. The primary finding of the report is that while there is some need for new energy programs, there is a more pressing  need for environmental and energy technology to be incorporated into existing programs. Additionally, the cost of creating new programs is prohibitive for many colleges, whereas modifying or reconfiguring existing programs to incorporate environmental and energy job skills would be more useful. Therefore, ATEEC has conducted job task analyses  or DACUMs (Developing A CurriculUM) for two-year programs to assist in enhancing current programs or developing new ones.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Advanced Technology Environmental and Energy Center (ATEEC), an NSF ATE Center of Excellence, was established in 1994 with a mission to advance environmental technology education through curriculum development, professional development and program improvement in community colleges and secondary schools. In 2003, ATEEC became an ATE Resource Center and in 2007, ATEEC was additionally tasked with expanding its expertise to build up sustainable energy technology resources to meet the needs of students, educators, and industry to supply the sustainable energy field with trained technicians. ATEEC is operated through Eastern Iowa Community Colleges (EICC) and partners with the National Partnership for Environmental Technology Education (PETE) and the University of Northern Iowa (UNI). ATEEC continues to evolve in order to better meet the changing needs of educators, students, technicians, and related NSF ATE projects to prepare environmental and energy technicians for current and future jobs. In August 2011, ATEEC opened new facilities which house ATEEC offices; the Interactive Learning Lab; classrooms and labs for credit and non-credit training programs; Environmental Health and Safety offices; and a Local Leaders exhibit showcasing local technology innovations to grow the entrepreneurial culture in environmental and energy fields. The new facility has allowed ATEEC to enhance the environmental and energy knowledge of educators, students, technicians, employers, and the public. This past year alone, the Interactive Learning Lab has been visited by over 4,500 people (mostly students). While at the lab, visitors can interact with diagnostic systems for solar panels and wind turbines which provide real-time energy production data, watch educational careers videos demonstrating various sustainable energy jobs and required skill sets for the jobs, and participate in a variety of hands-on STEM activities. ATEEC also expanded international activities. The partnership with Dalum College of Agriculture and the EUC-Syd Technical College in Denmark was enhanced through an NSF supplemental grant that allowed community college faculty and students from across the country to participate in a four-week institute in Denmark to study agriculture-based renewable energy technology in Europe. Information gained through international activities is incorporated into ATEEC activities, environment and energy curricula and the Resource Center website. ATEECÆs activities are built on the specific needs of the nationÆs environmental and energy education programs by facilitating occupational analysis workshops and forums across the country to ensure the input of business and industry. In 2009 and 2010, ATEEC facilitated NSF-funded Regional Energy Conversation forums to obtain a snapshot of existing and emerging energy jobs and to determine which jobs are currently needed and will soon be needed in different regions of the country in the area of energy. Information gathered from these forums was verified and validated at the National Energy Technician Education Summit held in December, 2010 in Washington, DC. Results can be found in ATEECÆs Preparing Energy Technicians for the 21st Century Workforce report. The primary finding of the report is that while there is some need for new energy programs, there is a more pressing need for environmental and energy technology to be incorporated into existing programs. Additionally, the cost of creating new programs is prohibitive for many colleges, whereas modifying or reconfiguring existing programs to incorporate environmental and energy job skills would be more useful. Therefore, ATEEC has conducted job task analyses or DACUMs (Developing A CurriculUM) for two-year programs to assist in enhancing current programs or developing new ones.
